value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">37</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>meditayions</sic>
              <corr>meditations</corr>
            </choice>. The vast accumulations, of 
            <choice>
              <sic>lear ing</sic>
              <corr>learning</corr>
            </choice>, that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have filtered from books into the quiet college room</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">meander over the page. He sees through a thousand <quote source="#" rend="inline">green 
            <choice>
              <sic>shads</sic>
              <corr>shades</corr>
            </choice></quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">what lies 
            <choice>
              <sic>immidately</sic>
              <corr>immediately</corr>
            </choice> before him-- the unhappy heart of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">man. The reflections serve to chequer the immediate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spectacle. From books he has won the tolerant sense</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that we are not 
            <choice>
              <sic>singl</sic>
              <corr>single</corr>
            </choice> figures but innumerably 
            <choice>
              <sic>rep ated</sic>
              <corr>repeated</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">In pursuit of melancholy he travels over the whole world,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">though he has never left his college room. We are at a remove</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from the thing treated. We are enjoying the spectacle of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">melancholy, not sharing is anguish.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is here then that we develop 
            <choice>
              <sic>facuoties</sic>
              <corr>faculties</corr>
            </choice> that</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the play left dormant. to stop; to pause; to 
            <choice>
              <sic>refelct</sic>
              <corr>reflect</corr>
            </choice>;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to Now the reader is completely in being. He can</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">pause; he can ponder; he can compare; he can draw back from</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the page and see behind it a man sitting alone in the centre</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the labyrinth of words in a college room 
            <choice>
              <sic>thinkinh</sic>
              <corr>thinking</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of suicide. He can gratify many different moods.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He can read directly what is on the page, or, drawing</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aside, can read what is not written. There is a long drawn</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">continuity in the book that the 
            <choice>
              <sic>paly</sic>
              <corr>play</corr>
            </choice> has not. It gives a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">different pace to the mind. We are in a world where</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nothing is concluded.</l>
